author: sky.cactus
content: EIPs are *only* technical standards.  They do not even necessarily describe a change to Ethereum mainnet.

author: sky.cactus
content: We have specs that only apply to other Ethereum-like chains, and we have specs that have never been deployed to any chain.

author: sky.cactus
content: And there are changes to Ethereum mainnet that don't have EIPs describing them.

author: sky.cactus
content: An analogy, there are many standardized things in the world that don't have RFCs, and there are many RFCs that no one follows.  The RFC process is still useful as a place to put things that you can then point at later, especially when your thing is too small to warrant its own process/site.

author: djrtwo
content: I see 1.0 and 2.0 as misnomers implying a false sequentiality. What eth2 is, is essentially the replacement of the relatively simple PoW consensus mechanism for a much more sophisticated PoS mechanism. What eth1 is (when you swap out the PoW for eth2/PoS) is the user layer. The goal is to hot swap the consensus of the existing chain (becoming a shard) with a defined interface between these two layers. I think this division of consensus and user layer is natural and an ongoing split of specs will make sense
